channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tradition Saves Camels’ Spot in Jordan’s Desert Forces
item.description: Jordan’s Royal Desert Forces, descended from a camel corps, still rely on the animals for work like catching smugglers and recovering stolen cars on rough terrain.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Royal Desert Forces, who are Bedouin in Wadi Rum, Jordan, last month.

item.title: Japanese Unearth Remains, and Their Nation’s Past, on Guadalcanal
item.description: Expeditions to the South Pacific island where many thousands died reflect a surge in interest among young Japanese in World War II.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A Japanese vessel was partly submerged off Guadalcanal in 1942 after being hit by American forces. The battle helped turn the Pacific war in favor of the United States and its allies. Some 7,000 Japanese were reported missing on Guadalcanal.

item.title: In Comeback Stride, Sarkozy Wins French Party Leadership
item.description: With a preliminary total of 64.5 percent of the vote, the former president gained control over the center-right opposition and established a steppingstone in his attempt to run the country again.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Open Source: Egyptian Activists Protest Mubarak Verdict Online and Outside in a Sealed Tahrir Square
item.description: Activists who supported the uprising that drove Hosni Mubarak from power in 2011 jeered a court ruling acquitting him on Saturday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: As Mexico Addresses Climate Change, Critics Point to Shortcomings
item.description: Mexico has passed laws to regulate emissions and promote renewable energy, but some analysts doubt it will commit the resources to meet its much-lauded goals.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: President Ollanta Humala of Peru greeted Christiana Figueres, a United Nations official, on the eve of climate change talks.

item.title: Egyptian Judges Drop All Charges Against Mubarak
item.description: The court’s decision means former President Hosni Mubarak could go free for the first time since his 2011 removal from office.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Hosni Mubarak, the 86-year-old former president of Egypt, was brought back to a military hospital after a court appearance on Saturday.

item.title: Amid Slump, Brazil Congress Seeks Raise
item.description: Seizing on a generally sleepy time in Brazil, congressional leaders in the capital, Brasília, are pushing ahead with legislation to raise their own salaries as much as 34 percent.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Independent Is Elected Taipei Mayor as Taiwan’s Governing Party Falters
item.description: The election results signaled that Taiwan’s governing Chinese Nationalist Party, known as the Kuomintang, would be hard-pressed to retain the presidency in the 2016 election.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jiang Yi-huah of Taiwan, after the trouncing of the Kuomintang on Saturday.

item.title: Pope Brings Message of Interreligious Peace to Istanbul
item.description: The pope’s visit to Turkey is considered a message of solidarity with the Ecumenical Patriarchate of the Orthodox Church, which represents nearly 300 million Orthodox Christians worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Pope Francis visited Haghia Sophia, once a Christian temple and then a mosque, now a museum in Istanbul, on Saturday.

item.title: Taliban Overrun an Afghan Army Base
item.description: The insurgents killed as many as 14 soldiers in one of their deadliest attacks against Afghan soldiers this year, local officials said.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Tales Told Out of School in Pyongyang Cause Stir
item.description: A memoir by a Korean-American author about teaching English to adolescent boys at a private university in Pyongyang has angered the authorities and her former colleagues.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Suki Kim wrote a book about her experiences teaching at a North Korean university.

item.title: Attack in Western China Leaves at Least 15 People Dead
item.description: The police in Xinjiang shot dead 11 members of a gang who killed four people and wounded 14 in an attack on a busy street, official Chinese media said.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Conservationists Continue Push to Block Hong Kong Ivory Sales
item.description: Protesters gathered Saturday outside a Hong Kong department store that had been prominently selling ivory products, part of an effort to publicize the city’s key role in the trade.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ann E. Carlson and Alex Wang on the U.S.-China Climate Accord
item.description: Alex Wang and Ann E. Carlson, law professors at the University of California, Los Angeles, who study environmental policy and regulations in the United States and China, responded to questions about the United States-China agreement on cutting greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A man wears a mask to protect against polluted air outside the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Opinion: African Books for Western Eyes
item.description: The continent’s writers are being celebrated, but only for catering to Western tastes.
item.dc:creator: By ADAOBI TRICIA NWAUBANI

item.title: Roberto Gómez Bolaños, the Mexican Comedic Artist ‘Chespirito,’ Dies at 85
item.description: The actor, writer and director was known around the Spanish-speaking world for his iconic characters and widely viewed television shows.
item.dc:creator: By ELIAS E. LOPEZ
item.media:description: Roberto Gómez Bolaños as his famous character El Chavo.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Drafts Its First Domestic Violence Law, but Rights Advocates Say It Falls Short
item.description: Lawyers and women’s advocates welcomed the proposed national law, but said there were loopholes that would allow police officers to shirk taking action on those calls at their discretion.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Families visiting Tiananmen Square in Beijing. The proposed Anti-Domestic Violence Law aims “to preserve equal, harmonious and civilized family relationships."

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Very Modern Take on a Classic Chinese Painting
item.description: The artist borrows the visual and conceptual framework of “Along the River During the Qingming Festival,” a 12-century painting, to produce a patchwork of vignettes of everyday Chinese society.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A scene showing fishermen demanding payment before handing over the bodies of students who died while trying to save drowning children.

item.title: Shatila Journal: Palestinian Refuge for 6 Decades, Now Flooded From Syria
item.description: The Syrian civil war has driven a wave of Syrians into Lebanon, roughly doubling the population of the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main market in the Shatila refugee camp, one of two such rapidly growing settlements on the edge of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: 6 Are Killed in Egypt After a Call for Protests Rattles the Authorities
item.description: The reaction to scattered violence showed officials’ anxiety over insurgent threats.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Egyptian security forces stood guard on Friday in Matareya, on the outskirts of Cairo, where at least three protesters were killed in clashes with the police.
